comments.text: I usually got a ride here in less than 2 minutes. Has enough space for cars to pull down, simply perfect! [AdrianB] -HUNGAROHITCH for prez!
This is a really good place for hitching down south towards the coast. Had to wait about 10-15 minutes. I would walk onto the highway ramp to catch as many cars as possible.

Didn't wait at all, the first Icelandic car I waved down stopped :D

Hitching in Iceland in October was unbelievably easy - the first day I got 7 rides east on the Ring Road and didn't wait once over 5 minutes. Icelanders pick up so much and so fast. They told me in the summer it gets really crowded with hitch-hikers and they often don't have space, so I was apparently lucking out on hitching in the fall :) Was a bit chilly and dark to camp out though.

Hitching up to Höfn couldn't be easier, th

If you are heading south using the road no. 1 towards Selfoss then this is the place where to wait in Reykjavik.

There is a big Olís gas station nearby (before the roundabout) but I prefer to wait after the roundabout - cars are passing by slowly and it's not so busy place. But it depends on your preferences - both possibilities are great.

You can walk there or get there by bus no. 19 or 5 (station Helluvað).

Each three sides of the roundabout are perfect for thumbing. Northwards and Southwards it will be very quick (usually it was 2-3 minutes tops), but direction Pingvellir and along road 36 it might be a bit slower, as less traffic goes there. From here I managed to hitchhike to Selfoss several times through Pingvellir at 10pm, so everything is possible in Iceland! x)  [AdrianB]
Great spot, got a ride in less than 10 minutes! You may catch a ride to North or to the Geysir!
My 1st hitch hiking experience was here, got a ride in 5 min towards North! :) great spot!
I am not sure which place is referred to here, but Kópavogur is on the other side of Reykjavík, towards Keflavík.

Most people who drive past you here are going at least to Borgarnes, and this is a nice place for them to stop and pick you up. Bus 15 stops in MosfellsbÃ¦r, from there you'll need to walk a little bit to get to this point.
The first car stopped!
Very good spot. Many people will go all the way to Reykjavik.
Also good dumpster diving possibilities at the supermarket!
about the waiting times: no bullshit. the last two times there i have been picked up by the first car coming by.
This roundabout is the obvious spot when going on Road #1 from Hveragerði to Reykjavík and there's lots of space for cars to stop.
The best place to hitchhike from Akureyri towards East. Stand a few metres away from the place where cars are leaving the petrol station.
There's a cool place to pull over next to the gas station, there were two of us hitchhiking there and it didn't take long to get a ride even with almost no traffic
Wide space to pull over right after the gas station. You may see airplanes taking off if you are lucky.

Even if you don't like asking around, it's a very small airport so it's very easy to walk out to the road and stick your thumb out. If you walk about 500m from the first parking lot there's a junction from an internal road from which airport employees and people picking up rental cars might come out, so it's good to stand right in front of it.
I got a ride to Reykjavik, just by asking people who were on the same plane as me.
Asking people on the airport works great. I went out to the parking lot and got a ride within 5 minutes.
really great spot, not to much space for stay but cars ride slowly and its possible to take you fast
Depends on the days of the week but a really good spot generally
On our walking way to the bathh nearby thhe birds attachehd us, so we decided to hh..
Great spot to Isafjördur.
lay-by.
at the exit of the gas station for cars going south. This gas station is where most people driving between akureyri and reykjavik stop to rest.
Great spot for getting to Akureyri. used it on a weekly basis for months, never took more then 30 minutes. Gasstation/busstop near by as back up.
5 minutes and got a ride to the airport. Hitching in Iceland is so easy!

Hitching west to Keflavik Airport. Lots of cars and shoulders are wide to pull over without problems.

You can get close with bus 1 - gotta walk like 1 km from the bus stop. It goes right from the centre and costs 350 ISK, which is about 2 EUR.
Very good place to head over to Thingsvellir. Good reachable from Selfoss by walking a gravel road, starting at the gravel plant.

Great spot to hitch hike out of the cliff. Cars drive slowly, drivers can see you from distance and there is a FREE camping spot with water and toilet. So if you get stuck there, you can spend a night there without any problem.
As mentioned, there's a map area with a turnoff for cars that's perfect to stand by.

Just out of town, opposite the food shop, there is a good place for the cars to stop. Everyone will be going at least to Egilsstaðir. I hitchhiked here just after the arrival of the weekly boat from Denmark/Faroe Islands so there was lots of traffic.
The spot to go south (to Flokkalundur, the ferry etc.)
direction Reykjavik, after a hike to Glymur. late Saturday evening. Not so much traffic.
A good place for going around Hvalfjörður (or to the tip of it for a hike to Glymur). There is not so much traffic but we didn't have to wait long.

There's a nice HH spot towards Vík just before the bridge. Cars can stop there safely.
It's very common to hitch-hike there.
Rides available to the various small villages on the west coast, as far as Þingeyri.

Got dropped off by my first ride from Hvollsvöllur here at the car park for Seljalandsfoss. Went around to ask cars leaving for a lift to Skogarfoss and literally the first car i asked was happy to take me there. Super friendly tourists - a couple from Costa Rica
Super easy. Stood on the grass verge next to the N1 gas station in Hvolsvöllur. Was headed towards Skogar and was given a lift by a friendly czech couple to Seljalandsfoss
Great spot
A good spot.
super cool spot
Best spot in direction to Kirk and the east coast.
This was my first hitch ever. First time I put out my thumb the first car that passed me kicked me up. He was a semi-pro Icelandic footballer
The only car to pass me all day passed by, then put it in reverse ~200m to pick me up. Cute old couple going to the hospital.
Locals are helpful, traffic wasn't too busy but after 5 minutes I got a ride

Single lane road but with a biiiggg hard shoulder. Traffic slowed by bridge good visibility, had a sign saying airport, ride in 5 minutes at 8pm. Thank you Iceland!! 2 minute walk away from the number 1 bus from Iceland centre (~500kr cash, the driver said, "whatever you have"
Cool spot to get a ride towards Selfoss/Reykjavik
Really few cars but they stop and drivers are friendly.
Good spot. A lot of traffic. Even though the cars are going relatively fast, they can see you and will stop. There is even space for pulling over.
Good spot. You can get here by bus from Reykjavik
good spot

This is the best place for hitchhiking if you're leaving the ReykjavÃ­k area to the north. Cars are slowed down here right after the roundabout and they have space to stop on the shoulder to pick you up.

The BEST spot, 5 min walk from airport, slow traffic, good visibility, tons of space to pull over in a shoulder and lay by. Used thumb, no asking needed, ride to Reykjavik in 2 mins! Driver spoke English, damn that was easy!!
A lot of space for cars. I spend 3 minutes here.
Good spot. Safety. You can catch cars on both sides. behind the station and right off the road, because there is a large, wide side.
Waiting here next to the gas station might be better than the spot a bit further down. There is a lot of space. I have hitched here many times.
Still working spot. Cars are going uphill and you have a chance to catch something. There's a wide, safe side path.
Got a ride all the way to Selfoss
Actually the best way to get out of Vík. Just go to the city-limit sign, where also the weather-information table is. Good place for stopping.
I recommend to walk 500m backwards, there is a nice and loooong bus stop, so cars can stop easily! ;]  [AdrianB]
Excellent for hitchhiking toward Akranes
The best spot to leave Akureyri to North/Northwest/West, it takes a little bit to walk to this spot, but it is absolutely recommended.

Good place to stand. The road is a bit wider after the junction so cars can stop. Also gas station is nearby in case you need to buy something or get shelter. I stood there with a sign saying Reykjavík for two hours between 17.30 and 19.30 in summer. Noone stopped. Stood there without a sign the next morning. Got a ride to Rvk within 30 minutes. HI Hostel is 10 minutes down the road past the Bónus store in case you need to crash somewhere.
A kind tourist picked the two of us up, and we continued our journey together along the south coast before heading back to Reykjavík. Bónus is no longer on the corner.
I wait a little further down the road before the "70" sign, there is a bit more space for them to stop.
Had to hitchhike in Selfoss, because our rental car broke down. It was easy, even with 3 people, we had a ride to Reykjavik after 5 minutes.

Good place at the end of the town to hitch-hike towards Hella and Vík. 

It's not the "top 10" place because there's not a lot of space to stop safely and a lot of cars are turning right to the supermarket just in front of you but if somebody wants to take you he will definitely stop here. Cars go still quite slowly.

Btw. There's a cheap supermarket "Bónus" just next to this hitch-hiking spot.
Really great spot to go north
Also good dumpster diving possibilities at the local supermarkets!
The place to be if heading to Reykjavik. Go just a little past the shopping center, before the bridge, and you'll find a spot with ample room for cars to stop.

Your way from Borgarnes to Snæfellsnes peninsula.

The traffic is lower but we didn't wait for a long time.

Not the best spot in the world but the there is quite a lot of cars and they go slowly because of the roundabout. We had to wait for an hour but we got a ride all the way to Reykjavík, our friends got a ride in a few minutes, depends ;)
Not a bad spot but in April, there weren't many cars going clockwise, after about an hour I managed to get a ride all the way to Akureyri.
Large road with a large bus stop (it's covered, so you can use it as a shelter when it's raining). Lots of people driving downtown, useful for outbound hitches as well.
We were heading to the south and the first car stopped. But there is a few people driving these road, so we were probably very lucky.
Actually we could get a ride eithher towards Tálknafjördur or Látrarbjarg to see theh puffins.

There is a traffic hhere, but soemtimes cars just doesnt want to stop for you.
After 8pm its just senseless.
We HH here towards Selfoss. The cars are going very fast, but finally somebody stopped. You can even go to the Hekla from here.
I guess we were HH hehre during the highest season in june, cause the second car stopped.

Hitch-hiking from Landmannalaugar is actually really possible! There are quite many cars, usually 4WD and SUVs leaving that place. But even smaller cars can get there and you can see them on the road (although it's officially prohibited).

You still need to wait some time - there's approximately about 1 car in 15 minutes but finally someone will always pick you up.
We hit the road here. you can get cheap food from the bonus and after you can start HH.
Really here is like an orkan wind. I guess we were lucky with waiting only around 15 minutes. We went to Reykjavík. But hehre is a nice gas station if it is open you can go in... and wait.

Here a nice natural thermal spring, with han amazing view to the mountains, where you can warm up. But be aware, if you want to stay for thhe night. This fjord is pretty open to the cold and strong northern winds. During the night its better to sleep at the changing room.
We waited around 30 min in rain, but than a girls just stopped and drove us untill Patreksfjordur.
It is a great spot towards to the westfjords.
Straight after the bridge, there's a cool spot to pull over. Don't go all the way to the gas station though as the cars go quite fast there and it's hard to spot you from distance.
very little traffic in the morning.
towards Hofn
From the spot you can get the slow traffic from the access road of Hofsos (pretty town, worth a visit).
Good place going westwards.

Right on the top of the mountain is a perfect place to be. Cars can see you from afar and have even to get slower at an obstacle for the sheep. Furthermore there is perfect space to stop by. Reykjavík is only 50km.
Enough cars pass through , thus someone will definetely take you :)
For going to Reykjavik, there is a spot where cars can stop. Got a ride to Mosfellsbaer here after 2 minutes.

Esjuskáli is a parking lot where most people park their cars while climbing mount Esja. Bus 57 from Mosfellsbær also stops here (www.bus.is). You can either ask at the parking lot in case you need a ride to Reykjavík, or stay by the road if you are going north. This is  a nice place out of town for people going north. Although you can continue even further on bus 57 (costs more money though).
The spot to go south to Reðarfjörður.
The road to Neskaupstaður. Usually there's not much traffic, but it works.

If you want to leave Jökulsárlón and go to Höfn, be prepered for a little bit longer waiting period.
Many tourists are not going further east than to Jökulsárlón and there are not many locals passing by because there not many towns around this part of the road. 

But this is the spot where you can try to hitch-hike.
Nice place for HH towards Keflavik or Reykjavik. The amount of traffic is quite good.

If you want to do some hiking around Þingvellir then this is one of the places where you can re-appear back on the road and try to hitch-hike after the trek. 

There's a small place where cars can stop safely. But it's in the middle of nowhere in a forest - so be prepared and have some water with you. 

The amount of traffic is quite good at this road - many tourists passing by.
Could only get a ride as far as Súðavík, however longer rides must be available with patience.
Trying for a ride to the ring road, we found it surprisingly hard to do.
Got a ride for 3 people to Ísafjörður after 10 minutes.
Good spot for long rides in any direction, but one car every 5 minutes in summer daytime.

If you ask the driver of bus 57 (www.bus.is) to let you off after the tunnel (there is no stop there officially) you can stand on road nr 1 and avoid traffic going to Akranes, if you are going north. From here on most people will be going at least to Borgarnes. When you exit the tunnel, there are toll booths where most people stop to pay the tunnel fee, so that is also a good place for asking for rides.

Good spot in direction to RVK and KEF. Here ejst a popular turn to the black beach next to reynisfjara, as if here would beoc iut not ok, then a piece further on is a small aprking on the right side in the direction of RVK.
Good. You don't find anything better than this spot.
Some space to pull over after a speed bump
Good spot, a lot of traffic but still some space to pull over.
Good spot for heading north. The cars are going fast but they see you from a far away and there is plenty space to pull over. You can even ask people around on the parking lot but it’s not that busy.
Just before this spot there is a platform for crossing the street so the cars are going relatively slowly and there is nice spot where they can pull over. It’s a good place for heading north.
The place is as well great for watching the wales in the fjord(summer). Traffic gets pretty low in the late evening.
Started walking towards the next crossroads and hitched at the same time.
It can be quite windy at that spot. Supermarket and toilets nearby. Going north for a few 100m will give you some nice camping  options.

We were 2 people hitchiking from that spot, in general I think it's a good location. It's on the main ring road and there is a parking just in front  of the spot. I wouldn't recommend to anyone hitchhiking there in the winter because there is nothing near by , so if you end up waiting there for more than an hour it can be dangerous.
For direction Vík, just go until the little forest, in front of it, there is a little space for cars! Got a ride in less than 4 minutes each time. [AdrianB]
There is a long and safe space to pull down for the cars, so it's quite an easy and quick job there! [AdrianB]

This is very good spot to hitchhike, you have cars coming from 2 different directions and most of them are heading to Akureyri, we were 2 people and only waited 10 minutes to get a ride, also there is a minirmarket just next to it,
There's a good spot to pull over if you're going clockwise and most cars go to Dettifoss, maybe a bit further

Dont remember waiting time. But i got a ride from there all the way to Reykjavik. With a restaurant a jacuzzi and an appartement in Vik  for the night. My best hitchike experience ever. With two car full of friendly Pakistan.
Westward from Skaftafell. In the summer many cars will come out from the park's access road.

Nice spot when you wanna return to Reykjavik after enjoying a bath in a hot river (there is unpaved road heading close to Ring road). You should go a bit far from the turn to be visible for drivers who are going fast here.

Was trying to get a lift towards Selfoss or Reykjavik was hopeless as cars were approaching too fast to possibly stop and cars turning out from Skogarfoss were totally uninterested in stopping. Had to give up when it started getting dark and thus dangerous to be stood by the side of the road. Had to camp the night at Skogafoss. Would not reccomend this spot.
Waited 20 minutes because of another hitchhiking couple. After they gave up it tooks 2 minutes to get a ride.
There's a spot where the ring road meets the road to the Skogafoss waterfall. There are a lot of tourists heading here so it's good to go in the directions of Vik or Borganes.
Cars coming from both sides so some traffic in a otherwise isolated place.
Thumbing the traffic coming from patreksfjord. Got a long distance ride towards Reykjavik. Quiet road, limited space to pull over but it worked. Drivers spoke good English. Near the shipwreck

VERY DANGEROUS!!!
DONT GO HERE. ITS A HIGHWAY NOW
As the guy above, i waited 1min while actually was just walking with thumb out. Now i also have 4h until my flight...
Took me 12 minutes.
I got a ride to the airport within seconds, I didn't even have the chance to put my backpack down. IT was so quick I ended up with 4:30 hours to kill until my flight...

There aren't really any good spots here, but Bus number 1 from Reykjavik stops very near by (When you reach HafnarfjÃ¶rÃ°ur, just ask the driver to let you know when you're close to Reykjanesbraut) and you'll kind of have to walk along the road with your finger out. The road shoulder is not bad though, so cars can stop if they see you in time. Not good, but it works.
Hitching to Reykjahlíð is possible from here. Tourists mostly go first to Viti, and visit Leirhnúkur after that.
Tourists will go viti and Lerhnjukur. I got lucky and before I could lift my thumb, some tourists offered me a ride.
Not a bad spot if you wanna go anti-clockwise. I was heading north and it tok me a while to get a ride there.
Decent spot, caught a ride in minutes.
Parking area to go towards Akureyri. Not much traffic and many stop here to go to a cafe or tourist info.
Gravel road, changes to tarmac after a while. Not much traffic.
waited in the rain, traffic was tight but managed to catch a ride to Egilsstaðir in half an hour.
It may be difficult to leave the Reykjahlid area. You may want to walk all the way here and try with the tourists visiting the mud pools.
Make sure your ride goes at least to Reykholt, or you may get stuck in the middle of nowhere on this road. Amazing lunar landscapes.
An adventurous option if you are heading north and don't want to go back to H1. Very few cars are going to drive this way, but the barren highland landscape is incredible and worth the effort.
I got a ride from here to Mosfelsbaer. Maybe I was lucky. Not the best place to hitchhike.
Left after waiting for an hour, for a place 3km east on another entrance to the highway, caught a ride in minutes
for going south. A lot of local traffic.
A bit far out of town, but if someone can bring you there, it is the perfect spot to get out of Neskjaupstaður.

There are much more cars passing by to Höfn than going up to the north towards Egilstadir.
You ought to be patient if you want to go north.

Sometimes very little traffic, like a bit everywhere in this part of the island. If you're going to EgilstaÃ°ir, remember that you can't take the shorter mountain road (not on this map) unless you hitch a 4x4. In the summer, many drivers with rental cars don't know that. Knowing it will save you lots of time.
We were 3 people hitching north, and it took about 90 minutes to get a ride.
One car every 10 minutes on the route 68 in either direction, but one car every 5 minutes that takes the route 59. We were 3 people hitching north, and it took about 90 minutes to get a ride.

Although this map says this road is nr 848, some other maps claim it to be road nr 1 (the main road if you are going to Akureyri). There are many points of interest and small settlements around lake Mývatn so many people might be driving short distances here. However it is not difficult to get a ride at least to Akureyri.

A lot of flies next to the lake. Hiking is great on the ring road (the 1), but otherwise it's much harder on the more desolate places to find a good ride. Stay on the ring road, or be prepared for some walking :)
We waited long. Many tourists probably drove after the attractions, but when we wrote the card Reykjavik we catch in faster than with a thumb

It’s not a great spot, we just had to hitchhike there. There is a little space for cars to pull over on the junction but I wouldn’t recommend it. It didn’t took long at all but the cars were driving super fast. If you can, find a better place :D
Terrible spot
No sense to stay here. middle of traffic. Years ago had more sense, now totally nothing.
a little bit further down there is more space.

One of the few gas stations in this area. People usually stop here to get a fuel before they continue. 
The amount of traffic towards east is starting being very low but it's still OK and even if you wait longer you can always use the facilities at the gas station. So it's quite luxurious spot.
We tried to hitchhike here to get to Hekla "base camp". Actually there was plenty of cars, but those were usually full or just didn't stop. We went more than hour till the first car stopped.
It took all day, but we did make it to Landmannalaugar eventually, right before sunset, and all I needed was one look at the place with the evening light to decide it was definitely worth it.

Tried to hitch from here to Landmannalaugar, because it looked like the best option on the map. There's a gas station and a store where you can get food, and there's no problems for cars to stop, but there's not many cars and many of them were going a short distance.

Hitching on mountain roads in NOT easy! I ended up walking to the junction of 731 and 35 just out of boredom... I did end up getting a ride, but I probably waited 3+ hours for it (including the walk, in which a few cars passed me by). The good thing is that once you get a ride, it's virtually guaranteed to take you at least until Hveravellir, since there's virtually nothing in between. Really NOTHING. 
If you're gonna try to hitch Kjölur (the F35), be prepared for LONG waits and have the proper

Very few cars, mostly tourists with rental 4X4s (you're not allowed to go on the F roads without one). Most of the cars are full. Absolutely no problem to stop, of course, since there are 5 cars an hour at most...

Not many cars are using this road along the coast. Usually just some locals going only few kilometres and turning on the next crossroad. 

If you don't have really plenty of time, use the other bigger road to get to Keflavík.
Hitchiked here at night, after 3 p.m. ( getting dark early in the winter), 3-4 hours until someone stopped.Not many cars, maybe 3-4 cars per hour

Traffic is very low, few cars passes by per hour. From my experience locals didn't stop only tourists, unfortunately the latter ones were heading to the ferry direction brjánslækur and that wasnt our goal

Officially marked hitch-hiking spot towards the Keflavík airport but at a really senseless place. 
It's better to walk there.

Beyond this point the road to thorsmork is impossible without a super jeep, and traffic became very minimal. The handful of superjeeps which did pass all seemed to hate hitchhikers and just laughed. The big all terrain bus service eventually stopped but demanded 60 USD for 3 miles. Maybe I just got a bad day, but this wasn’t ideal and I walked the whole way. (5hrs) It was beautiful, but there are serious rivers to cross and the dust made breathing awful. The rest of Iceland was amazing for hitch
